content: When we type some or all of a theorem name in the argument of a tactic (like rw [mul_comm ...], sometimes hovering shows documentation for the theorem and sometimes shows a menu of completions of the name. How can we quickly control which of these is shown? Sometimes it shows what I want when I wait and sometimes it doesn't. I would think there is a short cut to control this; how would be find documentation for that?

Are you using VS Code? I'm not sure I've experienced hover giving me a menu of completions. To get the menu of completions I usually use ctrl-space. If a string doesn't correspond to a theorem/tactic then hover on it won't produce anything useful.

Yes, I'm using VS Code. I soon guessed and tried ctl-space but thanks for the tip. I have experienced that hovering sometimes produced a menu of completions, but it seemed unpredictable whether that menu or the documentation (nothing when the name was undefined) showed. Hovering also produced documentation on the tactic or highlighting in the Infoview of what the theorem applies do. It's very sensitive to which character position is hovered over. I also discovered that clicking on each pane of the documentation window kept it visible until I clicked somewhere else.

Where is documentation and/or a tutorial on features like this? PS. I just found the .pdf of shortcuts under the Help menu. :smile:
Hmm, I'm also not familiar with the "hover shows menu of completions". Would it be possible for you to post a screen-recording of this?

So, to double check: the completions menu shows up while typing? Not while moving around the mouse?
If so, that is expected behaviour.
But your original question, about showing completions vs docs might still be relevant.

Johan Commelin said:

So, to double check: the completions menu shows up while typing? Not while moving around the mouse?
If so, that is expected behaviour.

YES, thanks. That's what it does. Up to about 3 sec after the last letter keystroke, the completion menu appears; sometimes it appears a bit sooner or later. Early in session, it displays a "loading" box for a sizable (10 sec or so) time and then displays the menu. Then, (of course) repeating the same beginning letters makes the menu appear quickly. When I move the pointer on and off a partially typed symbol, a box with information about the "problem" appears and disappears on top of the completion menu. So this explains the design and how to use it. But it's still handy to know that ctrl-space brings up a completion menu when the cursor is inside partially-typed symbol. (When I do that action, the "loading" box and not-too-long pause appears first, even when the same completion had been done before.)

In short, I think it meets our needs well once we find out and get used to how the features interact!
